landing_page.sectionTitle1: The quick and easy way to create a declaration letter
landing_page.sectionParagraph1: This tool guides justice impacted individuals through the declaration letter writing process to accelerate their path toward record clearance.
landing_page.sectionParagraph2:
Expunge Assist is a non-profit organization under Hack for LA. We aim to help people with criminal records accomplish record clearance, expungement, or a reduction to their sentence.

As of now, this service is only available to people who have criminal records in California.
landing_page.sectionParagraph3: This is a tool for applicants who are writing a letter to a judge that addresses their progress and motivations for seeking expungement.
landing_page.sectionParagraph3BulletPoint1: Targeted question prompts guide the writer
landing_page.sectionParagraph4:
We provide step-by-step guidance through the
process of writing and downloading a letter to
a judge for your expungement application.
landing_page.sectionParagraph5a: This tool results in a complete and downloadable declaration letter.
landing_page.sectionParagraph5b: We recommend applicants meet with a lawyer or clinic to review the letter before submitting it to a judge.
landing_page.sectionParagraph6:
To keep your data safe, Expunge Assist does not share, store, or save anything you enter into this website on any server.

When you close the webpage, your data is erased forever, everywhere. Only you keep your downloaded or emailed copy.
landing_page.section7Dropdown1Title: Why do I need a declaration letter?
landing_page.section7Dropdown1Paragraph:
When you file a petition with the court, you have the opportunity to attach a personal letter called a “declaration letter” explaining why you deserve a fresh start.

The declaration letter is your opportunity to explain to a judge why you want your criminal record cleared or your charges reduced. A declaration letter can help your case by adding your personal reasons and motivation to your legal case.
landing_page.section7Dropdown2Title: Why does expungement or reclassification matter to me?
landing_page.section7Dropdown2Paragraph:
The word “expungement” can be confusing. Expungement means that in most cases your past criminal record cannot be used against you when applying for a job, housing or student loans. You also regain some of your rights like serving on a jury or owning a gun.

Even though your criminal record does not disappear from the public record forever, your record will be updated to show that the conviction has been dismissed.

Reclassification allows you to change past felony convictions to a misdemeanor, even if you have served a sentence and parole. Once the felony has been removed from your criminal record, you may be eligible for benefits not previously available to you.
landing_page.section7Dropdown3Title: Can law enforcement get a search warrant to access my data on this site?
landing_page.section7Dropdown3Paragraph: No. Even if law enforcement were to search this site for your data, there would be no data to find. We do not store or save any of your data, ever. There would be nothing to find.
landing_page.sectionParagraph8:
Expunge Assist is currently looking for partner organizations to refine and tailor the
product to the needs of their organizations. Contact us to learn more.

welcome_page.description: This tool will guide you through writing your declaration letter. You can preview your letter and make changes at the end of each section.

advice_page.header: Advice for a successful declaration letter

point1.content: Remember to avoid using informal language, such as abbreviations, slang and profanity:
point1.yes: Judge LastName, job, Department of Justice

point2.content: Remember to answer in complete sentences and use punctuation (like periods) at the end:
point2.yes: I want to expunge my record because I want to apply for jobs.

point3.content: Be sure to use “the first person” when answering questions. This is from your point of view:
point3.no: Kim wants to clear their record.
point3.yes: I want to clear my record.

advice_page.followUp: Keep your responses between 3-5 sentences for each section.

When you are done, email or download a copy of your letter.

faq_page.paragraph1: Expungement in California means that people with certain low level, non violent criminal convictions may clear their records, meaning the penalties of their crimes will be removed or reduced. Expungement lifts many of the negative consequences of a criminal record, giving people a fresh start to their lives.
faq_page.paragraph2: A “declaration letter” is sometimes called a “personal letter” or “personal statement.”
faq_page.paragraph2b: Your letter allows you to tell the judge your story.
faq_page.paragraph2c: A good letter shows your motivation and efforts to better your life since conviction, explains your personal story, and how expungement, reclassification, or reduction would make a difference for you.
faq_page.paragraph2d: It is often about one page long.
faq_page.paragraph2e: This is your story. Use the space to say what is important to you.
faq_page.title3: Why do I need a declaration letter?
faq_page.paragraph3: When you file a petition with the court, you have the opportunity to attach a personal letter called a “declaration letter” explaining why you deserve a fresh start.
faq_page.paragraph3b: The declaration letter is your opportunity to explain to a judge, in your own voice, why you want your criminal record cleared or your charges reduced. A declaration letter can help your case by adding your personal reasons and motivation to your legal case.
faq_page.title4: Why does expungement or reclassification matter to me?
faq_page.paragraph4: The word “expungement” can be confusing. Expungement means that in most cases your past criminal record cannot be used against you when applying for a job, housing or student loans. You also regain some of your rights, like serving on a jury or owning a firearm.
faq_page.paragraph4b: Even though your criminal record does not disappear from the public record forever, your record will be updated to show that the conviction has been dismissed.
faq_page.paragraph4c: Reclassification allows you to change past felony convictions to a misdemeanor, even if you have served a sentence and parole. Once the felony has been removed from your criminal record, you may be eligible for benefits not previously available to you.
faq_page.title5: Can law enforcement get a search warrant to access my data?
faq_page.paragraph5: No. Even if law enforcement were to search this site for your data, there would be no data to find. We do not store or save any of your data, ever. There would be nothing to find.
faq_page.paragraph5b: Once your data has left our site via download, it is your responsibility to keep your data secure.
faq_page.paragraph6: Proposition 47 changed the law in California so that six kinds of low level, non-violent crimes like theft or drug possession can be reduced from felonies to misdemeanors.
faq_page.paragraph6b_li1: If you have been convicted of a non-violent felony in the past, you can ask the court to have your felony reduced to a misdemeanor.
faq_page.paragraph6b_li2: If you are currently serving a sentence for a felony, you can ask the court to have your sentence reduced to a misdemeanor and be released.
faq_page.paragraph6b_li3: If you have already served a sentence for a felony, you can ask the court to reduce your old case to a misdemeanor.
faq_page.paragraph6c: Most importantly, Proposition 47 means if you are granted a reduction by a court, you can truthfully say you have never been convicted of a felony when asked on a job, housing, or other application.
faq_page.paragraph6e: For more information about Prop 47 exceptions and restrictions, visit
faq_page.paragraph7: Proposition 64 legalized the sale and use of recreational marijuana among people aged 21 and older in California.  At the same time, Proposition 64 also reduced or eliminated certain penalties related to previous marijuana convictions. If you qualify, you might be able to have your criminal record reduced or dismissed completely.
faq_page.paragraph7b_li1: Possession of marijuana or concentrated marijuana
faq_page.paragraph7b_li3: Possession with intent to sell marijuana
faq_page.paragraph7c: If you were between 18 and 20 at the time of the offense, it may be more likely that you can get your criminal records sealed and/or destroyed OR have the crimes reduced to a misdemeanor.
faq_page.paragraph7d: If you were charged with a Proposition 64 qualifying offense, you may apply to reduce your sentence if you are:
faq_page.paragraph7e: If you have already served a sentence for a Proposition 64 qualifying offense, you may apply for a reduction in your criminal charge.
faq_page.paragraph7f: There is no time limit for when you can apply for a reduction or dismissal under Proposition 64.
faq_page.paragraph7g: For more information about Proposition 64, please see
faq_page.title8: How is Proposition 64 different from Proposition 47?
faq_page.paragraph8: Proposition 64 differs from Proposition 47 in a few important ways. Passed in 2014, Proposition 47 made major changes affecting people charged with certain non-violent, low level crimes. Specifically, Proposition 47 reduced the legal penalties for six kinds of theft and drug possession charges from a more serious, a felony, to less serious, a misdemeanor. Passed in 2016, Proposition 64 built upon Proposition 47 by reducing or dismissing the remaining criminal charges for most marijuana convictions.
faq_page.paragraph8b: Most importantly, Proposition 47 means if you are granted a reduction by a court, you can truthfully say you have never been convicted of a felony when asked on a job, housing, or other application.
faq_page.paragraph9: Under Proposition 47, you must file the “Petition for Resentencing/Reduction to Misdemeanor” form with the Superior Court where you were convicted no later than Nov. 4, 2022.
faq_page.title10: What does the Expunge Assist website do?
faq_page.paragraph10: This website serves as a guide to create your own letter by taking you through the writing process step by step.
faq_page.paragraph10b: Please note that the website does not replace any professional legal advice you receive from an attorney.
faq_page.title11: Is there incorrect information on this website?
faq_page.paragraph11: Get in touch at info@expungeassist.org. The laws are changing often in California, and that could mean some information is outdated in this website. We strive to provide correct information, so please let us know if we missed something.
faq_page.paragraph11b: Please note: the information provided here is only a very brief overview.
